description: From Medieval Latin necessitātus, past participle of necessitō (“to make necessary”), from Classical Latin necessitās (“necessity, need”) + -ō. Necessitās is derived from necesse (“unavoidable”) (from ne- (“prefix meaning ‘not’”) + cessus (“conceded, given up, yielded”).

verbs.description: necessitate (third-person singular simple present necessitates, present participle necessitating, simple past and past participle necessitated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make necessary; to behove; to require (something) to be brought about. [from early 17th c.]
examples: The early departure of her plane necessitated her waking up at 4 a.m.
